com.reactivecascade.reactive

Class ReactiveValue<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.reactivecascade.reactive.Subscription<T,T>
      • com.reactivecascade.reactive.ReactiveValue<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IGettable<T>, INamed, IAtomicValue<T>, IReactiveSource<T>, IReactiveTarget<T>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    PersistentValue, ReactiveInteger, ReactiveLong

    public class ReactiveValue<T>
extends Subscription<T,T>
implements IAtomicValue<T>
    Thread-safe reactive display of a variable getValue. Add one or more IActionOne actions to update the display when the variable fires. Usually these can be added as Lambda expressions referencing the UI element you would like to track the variable's getValue in an eventually-consistent manner.

    Note the all get()-style actions will return the latest getValue. Therefore asynchronous calls may not result in all values

    Bindings are thread safe. All reactiveTargets will refire concurrently if the IThreadType allows, but individual reactiveTargets will never be called concurrently or out-of-sequence. Multiple changes to the bound getValue within a short time relative to the current speed of the IThreadType may coalesce into a single headFunctionalChainLink refire of only the most recent getValue. Bound functions must be idempotent. Repeat firing of the same getValue is filter under most but not all circumstances. This possibility is related to the use of WeakReference of the previously fired getValue of each headFunctionalChainLink to minimize memory load.

    • Method Detail

      • fire

        public void fire()
        Run all reactive functional chains bound to this ReactiveValue.

        Normally you do not need to call this, it is called for you. Instead, call set(Object) to assert a new value.

        You can also link this to receive multiple reactive updates as a down-chain IReactiveSource.subscribe(com.reactivecascade.i.action.IActionOne) to receive and store reactive values.

        You can also link into a functional chain to receive individually constructed and fired updates using 

                 myAltFuture.subscribe(value -> myAtomicValue.set(value))
        Both of these methods will automatically call fire() for you. You may want to fire() manually on app startup after all your initial reactive chains are constructed. This will heat up the reactive chain to initial state by flushing current values through the system. All methods and receivers within a reactive chain are supposed to be idempotent to multiple firing events. This does not however mean the calls are free or give a good user experience and value as in the case of requesting data multiple times from a server. You have been warned.

      • get

        public T get()
        Description copied from interface: IAtomicValue
        Get the current valueAR.

        The value returned may change at any time. Therefore if you need to use it several times, keep your algorithm internally consistent by keeping an unchanging copy in a local variable for the duration of the function. Your function should also re-start either directly or indirectly the next time the value changes.

        Specified by:
        get in interface IGettable<T>
        Specified by:
        get in interface IAtomicValue<T>
        Returns:
        the current value, next value in the series, or null of the series has ended

      • set

        public boolean set(T value)
        Description copied from interface: IAtomicValue
        Set the current value.

        In the case of ReactiveValue which also implements IReactiveSource, which will also trigger all down-chain IReactiveTargets to receive the update. Any associated chain will only fire if the value set is new, not a repeat of a previous value.

        Specified by:
        set in interface IAtomicValue<T>
        Parameters:
        value - the new value asserted
        Returns:
        true if this is a change from the previous value

      • compareAndSet

        public boolean compareAndSet(T expected,
                             T update)
        Description copied from interface: IAtomicValue
        Replace the current valueAR with an update, but only if the valueAR is the expected valueAR.

        This is a high performance concurrent atomic compare-split-swap. For more information, see AtomicReference.compareAndSet(Object, Object)

        Specified by:
        compareAndSet in interface IAtomicValue<T>
        Parameters:
        expected - - Must be of the same type as update and must be the current value or the state will not change.
        update - - The asserted new value.
        Returns:
        true of the expected value was the current value and the change of state completed successfully

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Description copied from class: java.lang.Object
        Returns a string containing a concise, human-readable description of this object. Subclasses are encouraged to override this method and provide an implementation that takes into account the object's type and data. The default implementation is equivalent to the following expression: 
           getClass().getName() + '@' + Integer.toHexString(hashCode())

        See Writing a useful toString method if you intend implementing your own toString method.

        Specified by:
        toString in interface IAtomicValue<T>
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a printable representation of this object.
